assemblage.title: Second Derivative of a Parametric Curve

statement.p: Find the value of the second derivative for the circle x = \cos t, y=\sin t when \theta = \dfrac{\pi}{3}

Let C be a curve defined by the parametric equations x = 2t^2, y = t^3-t.
Show that C has two tangents at the point (2,0) and find their equations
Find the points on C where the tangent is either horizontal or vertical
Determine when the curve is concave up or concave down
Sketch the curve using the information above

li.p: At t = \pm 1, the curve passes through (2,0) so we know that the curve has up to two tangent lines at that point. Then, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{3t^2-1}{4t}; evaluating at t = 1 gives \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{2} and at t = -1 gives \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -\dfrac{1}{2}.
This gives the tangent lines y = \dfrac{1}{2}(x-2) and y = -\dfrac{1}{2}(x-2)
The tangent line is vertical when 4t = 0, so when t = 0. This occurs at (0,0).

The tangent line is horizontal when 3t^2-1 = 0, or at t = \pm \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}. This gives two points, \lrpar{\dfrac{2}{3}, - \dfrac{2}{3\sqrt{3}}} and \lrpar{-\dfrac{2}{3}, - \dfrac{2}{3\sqrt{3}}}
Since \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} = \dfrac{6t}{4t} = \dfrac{3}{2}, the curve is always concave up.

assemblage.title: Area Under a Parametric Curve
assemblage.p:
Let C be a curve traved out exactly once by the parametric equation x = f(t) and y = g(t). Then, the area under C between x = a and x = b is given by
A = \ds \int_a^b y\, dx = \int_\alpha^\beta g(t)f'(t)\, dt
or
A = \ds \int_a^b x\, dy = \int_\alpha^\beta f(t)g'(t)\, dt \text{ as a function of }y
where \alpha \leq t \leq \beta or \beta \leq t \leq \alpha, depending on direction of travel.

proof.p: If y = F(x), then the area is A = \int_a^b F(x)\, dx = \int_a^b y\, dx. In parametrics, F(x) = g(t) and \dfrac{dx}{dt} = f'(t)\iff dx = f'(t)\, dt.
If x = F(y), then the area is A = \int_a^b F(y)\, dy = \int_a^b x\, dy. In parametrics, F(y) = f(t) and \dfrac{dy}{dt} = g'(t)\iff dy = g'(t)\, dt

statement.p: Use the parametrization x = r\cos\theta, y = r\sin\theta (0\leq t\leq 2\pi) to show that the (unsigned) area of a circle is exactly \pi r^2
Show that the area under one arch of the cycloid x = r(\theta - \sin\theta), y = r(1-\cos\theta) is exactly three times the area of the generating circle.

solution.p:
If f(\theta) = r(\theta-\sin\theta) and g(\theta) = r(1-\cos\theta), then we have f'(\theta) = r(1-\cos\theta). Our parametrization runs 0\leq \theta \leq 2\pi , as each arch can be shown to be distance 2\pi r from each other.
\ds \int_\alpha^\beta y\, dx \amp \ds \int_0^{2\pi} r^2(1-\cos\theta)^2\, d\theta \amp = r^2\lrpar{\dfrac{1}{4}(6x-8\sin x + \sin 2x)}\bigg\rvert_0^{2\pi} \amp = 3\pi r^2

statement.p: Find the area enclosed by the curve x = t^2-2t, y = \sqrt{t}, and the y-axis.

solution.p:
x = 0 \iff t = 0,2. Then, we integrate with respect to y and note that f(t) = t^2-2t, g(t) = \sqrt{t} and g'(t) = \dfrac{1}{2}t^{-1/2}. So,
\ds \int_\alpha^\beta x\, dy \amp = \ds \int_0^2 (t^2-2t)\lrpar{\dfrac{1}{2}t^{-1/2}}\, dt \amp = \ds \int_0^2 \dfrac{1}{2}t^{3/2} - t^{1/2}\, dt \amp = \ds \lrpar{\dfrac{1}{5}t^{5/2} - \dfrac{2}{3}t^{3/2}}\bigg\rvert_0^2 \amp = \dfrac{4\sqrt{2}}{5} - \dfrac{4\sqrt{2}}{3}

statement.p: Use the parametric equations x = a\sin\theta, y = b\cos\theta, 0\leq \theta \leq 2\pi, to show that the area contained in an ellipse is \pi ab

solution.p: The work is virtually identical to the unsigned area problem above; the difference is now that we have parameters a,b showing up.

assemblage.title: Arc Length of a Parametric Curve
assemblage.p:
If a curve C is described by the parametric equations x = f(t), y = g(t), for \alpha \leq t\leq \beta, where f' and g' are continuous on [\alpha,\beta] and C is traversed exactly once as t ranges from \alpha to \beta, then the length of C is given by
\ds L = \int_\alpha^\beta \sqrt{(f')^2 + (g')^2}\, dt

proof.p:
Adapt the proof for the arc length formula from Section 8.1; the Mean Value Theorem gives that \Delta x_i = f'(t_i)\Delta t and \Delta y_i = g'(t_i)\Delta t so that
|P_{i-1}P_i| = \sqrt{(\Delta x_i)^2 + (\Delta y_i)^2} = \sqrt{(f'(t_i))^2 + (g'(t_i))^2}\Delta t
Pushing to the integral gives the result.

statement.p: Find the length of one arch of the cycloid x = r(\theta - \sin\theta), y = r(1-\cos\theta)

solution.p:
f'(\theta) = r(1-\cos\theta) and g'(\theta) = r(\sin\theta), so
\ds \int_0^{2\pi} \sqrt{(r(1-\cos\theta))^2 + (r(\sin\theta))^2}\, d\theta \amp = \ds \int_0^{2\pi} r\sqrt{(1-\cos\theta)^2 + (\sin\theta)^2}\, d\theta \amp = \ds \int_0^{2\pi} r\sqrt{2-2\cos\theta}\, d\theta \amp = \ds \int_0^{2\pi} r\sqrt{4\sin^2\lrpar{\dfrac{\theta}{2}}}\, d\theta \amp = \ds 2r \int_0^{2\pi} \sin\lrpar{\dfrac{\theta}{2}}\, d\theta \amp = \ds 2r \lrpar{-2\cos\lrpar{\dfrac{\theta}{2}}}\bigg\rvert_0^{2\pi} \amp = 4r(1+1) \amp = 8r

statement.p: Prove that the circumference of a circle of radius r is 2\pi r

solution.p:
Chose parametrization x = r\cos 2\pi \theta, y = r\sin 2\pi\theta. Then, x' = -2\pi r\sin 2\pi\theta and y' = 2\pi r\cos 2\pi \theta and
\ds \int_0^1 \sqrt{(-2\pi r\sin 2\pi\theta)^2 + (2\pi r\cos 2\pi \theta)^2}\, d\theta = \int_0^1 2\pi r\, d\theta = 2\pi r

statement.p: Find the exact length of the curve x = 1+3t^2, y = 4+2t^3, 0\leq t\leq 1
Find the exact length of the curve x = e^t\cos t and y = e^t\sin t, 0\leq t\leq \pi

p.m: \int_0^1 \sqrt{(e^t\cos t -e^t\sin t)^2 + (e^t\cos t + e^t\sin t)^2}\, dt = \int_0^\pi \sqrt{2}e^t = \sqrt{2}(e^\pi - 1)
